categories.name: Realism
categories.description: Focuses on depicting subjects as they appear in everyday life, without embellishment or interpretation.

categories.name: Impressionism
categories.description: Captures the impression of a moment, especially in terms of light and color. Often characterized by visible brush strokes.

categories.name: Cubism
categories.description: Breaks objects into geometric shapes and presents multiple perspectives simultaneously. Often abstract.

categories.name: Post-Impressionism
categories.description: Builds on Impressionism but emphasizes more on geometric forms, distortion for expressive effect, and the use of unnatural or arbitrary color.

categories.name: Expressionism
categories.description: Focuses on representing emotional experiences rather than physical reality. Often uses bold colors and exaggerated forms.

categories.name: Surrealism
categories.description: Features dream-like scenes and illogical, fantastical images. Emphasizes the subconscious mind.

categories.name: Abstract Expressionism
categories.description: Focuses on expressing emotions through abstract forms, often with a sense of spontaneity and personal expression.

categories.name: Pop Art
categories.description: Incorporates imagery from popular and mass culture, such as advertising, comic books, and everyday objects. Often uses bright colors and bold graphics.

categories.name: Fauvism
categories.description: Characterized by bold, often distorted forms and vibrant colors. Focuses on painterly qualities and strong color over representational or realistic values.

categories.name: Art Nouveau
categories.description: Emphasizes ornamental style with flowing, sinuous lines and often incorporates floral and other natural forms.

categories.name: Baroque
categories.description: Known for its grandeur, drama, movement, and tension. Often features intense contrasts of light and dark.

categories.name: Rococo
categories.description: Light, ornate, and decorative style that often depicts themes of love, nature, and playful subjects.

categories.name: Neoclassicism
categories.description: Draws inspiration from the "classical" art and culture of Ancient Greece and Rome. Emphasizes simplicity and symmetry.

categories.name: Romanticism
categories.description: Emphasizes emotion, individualism, and the glorification of the past and nature. Often dramatic and intense.

categories.name: Symbolism
categories.description: Uses symbolic images and indirect suggestion to express mystical ideas, emotions, and states of mind.

categories.name: Photorealism
categories.description: Focuses on creating paintings that are extremely realistic, often resembling high-resolution photographs.

categories.name: Minimalism
categories.description: Characterized by simplicity and the use of a minimal number of elements. Focuses on the essentials.

categories.name: Op Art
categories.description: Uses optical illusions to create a sense of movement or warping in the viewer's perception.

categories.name: Art Deco
categories.description: Combines modernist styles with fine craftsmanship and rich materials. Often characterized by bold geometric shapes.

categories.name: Dadaism
categories.description: An avant-garde movement that emphasizes absurdity and the irrational. Often uses found objects and nonsense.

categories.name: Constructivism
categories.description: An artistic and architectural philosophy that originated in Russia, characterized by abstract and austere compositions.

categories.name: Futurism
categories.description: Emphasizes speed, technology, and modernity. Often features dynamic movement and the energy of the modern world.

categories.name: Neo-Expressionism
categories.description: Revives the expressiveness of early 20th-century Expressionism, often with a raw, emotional quality.

categories.name: Luminism
categories.description: An American landscape painting style characterized by effects of light in landscapes, through the use of aerial perspective and the concealment of visible brushstrokes.

categories.name: Primitivism
categories.description: Borrowing visual forms from non-Western or prehistoric peoples, often characterized by a simple, unsophisticated style.
